key_points: Thousands of Americans living abroad received stimulus checks during the Covid-19 pandemic.
Over 3.7 million payments worth $5.5 billion were sent outside the 50 states and Washington, D.C.
Payments were part of three rounds of pandemic-era payments authorized by Congress.
Eligible recipients included U.S. citizens abroad, military members stationed overseas, and residents of U.S. territories.
The overseas payments accounted for less than 1% of the total stimulus funds.
Stimulus checks are technically advance payments of the recovery rebate tax credit.
The primary intent of the checks was to support household finances amid the pandemic.
Experts argue that the location of U.S. citizens (domestic or abroad) doesn't matter in a global pandemic.
Mistaken payments were made, including to non-citizens and in the form of duplicate payments.
IRS reportedly correctly paid at least 98% of first-round funds, despite some errors.
spokespersons: Kyle Pomerleau (Senior Fellow, American Enterprise Institute)
Janet Holtzblatt (Senior Fellow, Urban-Brookings Tax Policy Center)
Garrett Watson (Senior Policy Analyst, Tax Foundation)
